plist.p: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Ecopetrol's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Erin (0:07), and I'll be your coordinator for today. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. We will be facilitating a question-and-answer session toward the end of today's conference.
I would now like to turn the call over to Alejandro Giraldo, Investor Relations, Director. Please proceed.

Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Ecopetrol's first quarter 2012 financial and operational results conference call. Before we begin, it is important to mention that the comments by Ecopetrol's senior management could include projections of the company's future performance. These projections do not constitute any commitment as to future results nor do they take into account risks or uncertainties that could develop. As a result, Ecopetrol assumes no responsibility in the event that future results are different than the projections on the conference call.

The call will be led by Mr. Javier Gutiérrez, CEO of Ecopetrol. Also participating will be Adriana Echeverri, CFO; Héctor Manosalva, Executive VP for E&P; Pedro Rosales, Executive VP for Downstream; Álvaro Castañeda, VP of Transportation and Logistics; and Enrique Velásquez, VP of Exploration.
I will now turn the call over to Mr. Mr. Gutiérrez.

Thank you, Alejandro. Good afternoon. Thank you all for joining us in this conference call. Initially, we will provide a summary of our key financial results, the highlights of the business segments and the milestones of internal consolidation. Then we will close our presentation with an outlook for the second quarter and finally we will have a Q&A session. So let's turn to slide five to review our milestones in the first quarter.

The company continued making progress in its growth strategies, reaching higher level of production and achieving solid operating and financial results. The Corporate Group achieved in the first quarter a new record in production of 743,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. As in previous periods, the rise in production came from the fields in the Llanos region, mainly Castilla and Chichimene operated by Ecopetrol and from the association contracts in Rubiales and Quifa.

In line with the increases in production, the transported volume grew up to 1.2 million barrels per day of crude and products. Our sales volume grew due to the increases in the production of crude oil and natural gas. The sales prices were higher due to both the market conditions and our successful strategy of diversifying the benchmarks and the destinations for our crude. Thus, we increased the use of Brent crude as reference and the sales to the markets in Europe and the U.S. West Coast.

The higher prices and the increases in production led to the net income of COP$4.3 trillion, EBITDA amounted to COP$8 trillion. With regard to exploration, the companies of the Corporate Group drilled five exploratory wells in Colombia of which three have hydrocarbon presence. Also, it is worth to mention that Ecopetrol finalized drilling the Luna 1 well, our first step to test non-conventional reservoirs. Its results are under evaluation.

Additionally, we are on track. We've got modernization projects of our refineries, the expansion of our transportation infrastructure. Investments in the first quarter of 2012 total $1,107 million of which 63% were allocated to production, 15% to subsidiaries, 11% to Transportation, 6% to Exploration, 4% to Refining and Petrochemicals and the remaining 1% to Corporate segment.

Moving to HSE, our initiatives are providing a consistent trend of improvement in the safety of our operations. During the first quarter of 2012, the accident frequency rate was 0.99 accidents per million working hours compared with 0.94 in the previous quarter and 1.56 in the first quarter of 2011. Thus, the initiatives implemented have been effective for developing a safer operation for employees and contractors.
Now I would turn the presentation to Adriana Echeverri, who will comment on the financial results.

Thank you, Mr. Gutiérrez. Good afternoon, everyone. Let's turn to slide seven. In the first quarter of 2012, Ecopetrol had sound financial results driven by the increase in production and the higher prices of crude and products.

Starting on the left side of the slide, you can see how in the first quarter total sales rose compared to the same quarter in 2011. The exports including sales to Reficar free trade zones accounted for 68% of total sales. Total cost of sales plus operating expenses grew mainly due to the rise in variable costs coming from two sources. First, from larger purchases of crude oil from the National Hydrocarbons Agency, and second from higher input, mainly naphtha diluent and gasoline to supply the local market during the maintenance of the refineries in the first quarter.

Fixed cost increased mainly because of higher depreciation in contracted services related to larger production and maintenance activities. Those increases were offset by the decrease in the operating expenses, due mainly to the capitalization at the end of 2011 of the acquisition of Shell's stake in Cano Sur block, operating income amounted to COP$6.9 trillion in the first quarter of 2012, equivalent to an operating margin of 45%.

In the non-operating results, the loss of COP$0.5 trillion was mainly due to the adverse effect of revaluation of the Colombian peso and the impact of provisions mainly coming from the lower returns of the funds, which covers the pension liabilities. Total net income from the Group subsidiaries under the equity method amounted close to COP$444 billion as follows. Crude oil subsidiaries added COP$290 million, refining and petrochemical subsidiaries COP$119 billion, transportation subsidiaries COP$17 billion, and corporative subsidiaries COP$17 billion. Finally, net income amounted to COP$4.3 trillion, while EBITDA amounted to COP$8 trillion. EBITDA margin was 52% and net margin was 28%.

On the next slide, number eight, we find an overview of the company's cash flow and balance sheet as of the end of March. The initial cash balance was COP$9.2 trillion and cash generated from operations during the quarter amounted to COP$16.5 trillion. COP$7.2 trillion of the company's total cash flow were deployed to fund operations and COP$1.3 trillion for capital expenditures. The ending balance of cash and investments was COP$17.4 trillion pesos.

Regarding the balance sheet, total assets amounted to COP$93.2 trillion and total liabilities COP$46.1 trillion. The liabilities included the accrual of dividends for a total amount of COP$12.3 trillion approved by the general shareholders meeting and the higher provision for corporate tax that amounted to COP$8.4 trillion.

Financial debt was equivalent to 6.3% of total assets and to 12.7% of total liabilities, while debt-to-EBITDA ratio for the last 12 months was 0.2%. During the quarter, there was no increase in financial indebtedness. Finally, the equity decreased in the first quarter, mainly as a result of the recording of the accounts payable of the dividends declared in the general shareholders meeting held on March 22.

Now let's turn to the main aspects of the result of the Corporate Group shown on slide nine. In line with Ecopetrol results, in the first quarter of 2012 the Corporate Group reached solid financial results. Total sales for the Corporate Group amounted to COP$18 trillion compared with COP$14.4 trillion in the same quarter of 2011. Group's net income amounted to COP$4.3 trillion and EBITDA was COP$8.7 trillion while EBITDA margin was 49%.

Now let's move on to slide 10, and review the main figures of our subsidiaries. In the first quarter of the year, the highest revenue before accounting eliminations came from Reficar with COP$1.3 trillion, Hocol with COP$1.1 trillion and Equión with COP$0.6 trillion. Highest net income came from Equión with COP$219 billion, followed by Hocol with COP$187 billion, and Reficar with COP$117 billion. The figures with the highest EBITDA in the quarter were Hocol with COP$321 billion, Equión with COP$187 billion, and Ocensa with COP$148 billion.
Now I'll turn the conference to Enrique Velásquez, who will comment about the results of our E&P segment.

Please let's move on to slide 12, which summarizes the highlights of the E&P segment for the Corporate Group. Let's start with our production results. In the first quarter, the Corporate Group achieved a gross production of 743,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. During the quarter, production was affected due mainly to restrictions on the availability of transportation infrastructure. The production growth was led mainly by the increase in Castilla and Chichimene fields, which accounted for 152,000 barrels per day, Rubiales and Quifa for 121,000 barrels, and Nare for 17,000 barrels.

Regarding exploration, the companies of the Corporate Group drilled five A3/A2 exploratory wells in Colombia, of which wells Pintado and Dorcas drilled by Hocol had hydrocarbon presence. One of the wells was dry, and the remaining two were under valuation, including Tisquirama Este-1 well. Last week, hydrocarbon presence in the well was announced.

Also, as a Corporate Group eight tests were completed, of which two had evidence of hydrocarbons, the ST3A and the ST6 drilled by Hocol in the CPO 16 block. Another well is still under evaluation. This last one is our first in the positive aimed to add reserves for unconventional resources. As for the Caribbean offshore activity, during the first quarter, the rig Offshore Mischief arrived to Cartagena. This rig will be used to drill the wells Mapalé 1 and Mapalé 2 on block RC5 operated by our subsidiary, Equión.

Internationally, the appraisal well, Itauna 2, was drilled by our partner Anadarko in Brazil. Also in March, the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, BOEM, of the U.S. Department of Interior officially awarded to Ecopetrol America, Inc.. blocks East Breaks-284, 285, 328 and 329, located in deep waters of the East Breaks sector in the U.S. Gulf Coast. Additionally, the awarding of the block 623 at the Keathley Canyon sector was confirmed in February. Those resolutions allow Ecopetrol to incorporate five new wells into the portfolio in the U.S. Gulf Coast as a result of the Lease Sale 218.
Our 2012 drilling plans remain unchanged, that is to drill a total of 42 exploratory wells, 37 of them in Columbia, three in the U.S. Gulf Coast and two in Brazil.

Finally, let's review the financial result of the Upstream segment. Net income for the segment in the first quarter was COP$4.4 trillion. Overall results were driven by higher volume sold and better sales prices linked to benchmarks of the WTI. EBITDA amounted to COP$7.6 trillion equivalent to an EBITDA margin of 77%.
In summary, we continue making progress in our activities to accomplish the goals we have set for the year.
Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Álvaro Castañeda, who will provide an update on our midstream operations.

Good afternoon, everyone, and please turn to slide 13. The volume of crude and products transported by pipelines in the first quarter grew to 1.2 million barrels per day, of which 74% accounted for crude. Crude and naphtha volume transported by truck reached 104,000 barrels per day in the first quarter of 2012.

Regarding the Bicentenario pipeline, the segment between Araguaney and Banadía reached a 52% progress as of March 31. It is worth mentioning that Ecopetrol approved two key initiatives. First, the integrity program, which will enhance the current (17:24) in order to reach the highest industry standard. The budget for this initiative amounts to $489 million. The second initiative is a contingency program, which will review the potential consequence that might affect the communities and the environment in case of a failure in our transport infrastructure. The budget amounts to $39 million. This initiative will enhance the integrity and contingency management that is in Ecopetrol to minimize the risk that similar events as the Caño Limón-Coveñas crude oil pipeline and (18:00) product pipeline happen again.

Let's review the financial results of the segment. Net income amounted to COP$88 billion in the first quarter of 2012. Although revenue rose as a result of the higher production volumes in Colombia, gross expenses increased in the country due to maintenance expenditure on the transportation infrastructure. EBITDA margin was 56% and net margin was 14%.
With this, I will turn the presentation over to Pedro Rosales, who will comment on downstream results, starting with refining.

Good afternoon, everyone. Let's move on to slide 14. In terms of our operation, the refinery throughputs were reduced in the first quarter of 2012, mainly due to a scheduled maintenance of the bottom processing units at Barrancabaermeja refinery. During the execution of such maintenance, the production of valuable products was lower, impacting the result of refining gross margin.

The higher cost of crude, which is linked to the price of our crude export market, also affected the margin. Given the high crude prices, a scheduled maintenance, and therefore lower production of valuable products, which generated the need to increase inputs, the EBITDA was affected, reaching minus COP$43 billion, which corresponds to an EBITDA margin of minus 0.8% and a net loss of COP$156 billion for the quarter.

Regarding the main refining projects, the expansion and modernization of the Cartagena reported a 61% progress and the upgrading of the Barrancabaermeja refinery at 10% advanced. Finally, the master plan of utilities in Barrancabaermeja, which will update the infrastructure for the supply of steam, air, water and energy, reached 42% progress as of March 31.

Now please turn to slide 15 to review the sales and marketing results. Total sales volume grew between the first quarter of 2011 and 2012 due to the rise of exports. Export growth was driven by higher availability of Magdalena Blend crude and the increase of natural gas sales to Venezuela. These increases offset the reduction in local sales primarily of natural gas due to a lower consumption from thermal power plant and a new Decree recently issued allowing other producers to sell their oil and gas royalties. During the first quarter, we continued with the strategies of diversifying markets and referencing our crude to benchmarks that generate more value to the exports.

Regarding the destination of our exports, there was an increase in the market share for our crudes in the U.S. West Coast and Europe, as well as higher sales of fuel oils to Far East. These factors combined with increased demand for our heavy crude allows to improve $9 per barrel in the spread between our crude export basket price and Brent index. There were no export reference to WTI in the first quarter of 2012.

Lastly, the sales and marketing segment presented in the first quarter a net income of COP$41 billion lower than in the first quarter of 2011. This was the result of the higher transportation costs of crude and diluent for transporting heavy crude. EBITDA was COP$111 billion. EBITDA margin was 3% and net margin was 1.1%. There was also a significant non-operating impact due to the peso revaluation.

I now will turn the presentation back to Mr. Gutiérrez, who will comment on the milestones of the internal consolidation initiatives and the corporate social responsibility in the first quarter of this year.

Thank you, Pedro. Let's start with slide 17. I would like to start by highlighting the improvement in HSE. The accident frequency rate in the first quarter of 2012 was 0.99 accidents per million working hours compared with 0.94 in the previous quarter and 1.56 in the first quarter of 2011. Also the environmental incidents from operational causes fell to four in the first quarter of this year from 11 in the first quarter of 2011.

Those encouraging results strengthen our commitment of a safe and reliable operation. Also, it is worth to mention the technical corporation agreements with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the Petroleum Technology Alliance of Canada for identification and evaluation of opportunities to reduce greenhouse gases and increase energy efficiency.

Regarding our stakeholders, we have two important highlights during the quarter. First, on March 22, we held our annual shareholder meeting with a record attendance of more than 16,000 shareholders and the approval of a dividend of COP$300 per share payable in one installment for our minority shareholders.

The second highlight was the revision of some terms of the collective agreement, different than compensation and wages. This process was satisfactory for both the company and the unions. The agreement was signed in 2009 for a five-year period, and since the beginning this revision was established. Regarding science and technology our research institute was officially recognized as a research center by Colciencias, the governmental agency for science, technology and innovation.

In addition, the institute was granted by the Mexican government with patents for two additives helping improve visbreaking processes in refining and petrochemical areas. As a final point, I would like to emphasize that Ecopetrol remains fully committed with the community affected by the incident in Dosquebradas of last December. The company has continued its progress in all the work streams that is in health, housing, business and government, social, legal and environmental.

Finally, let's review the outlook for the second quarter of 2012. Please move on to the slide 19. During the second quarter of 2012, Ecopetrol will continue on its path to achieve all of our strategic goals for this year. Regarding exploration, Equión, our subsidiary, will begin the drilling in the Caribbean Colombian offshore. We will also complete the exploratory campaign of the quarter.

In production, we will continue rising our production in order to achieve the goal of 800,000 equivalent barrels per day in 2012. In transportation, we will continue achieving progress in our infrastructure projects, including the first phase of the Bicentenario Pipeline together with our partners. We also expect to consolidate the two initiatives our integrity of transport infrastructure and contingency, which are key to strengthen our infrastructure and improve the reliability of our operations.

The integrity program, with a total investment of $489 million, should assure a safe and reliable operation in our transportation system through monitoring of the critical variables in the infrastructure, continuous technological screening to evaluate threats and the implementation of the strengthened integrity management system.

On top of that, the contingency program intends to review the potential consequences that might affect the communities and the environment in case of any failure in our infrastructure throughout the assurance of a system of attention, the contingencies efficiently dimensioned, implemented and articulated along with other local and regional organizations and institutions. The approved budget to carry out the planned activities is $39 million.

In refinery, we will continue with the progress in the modernization of the Cartagena refinery, and with the arrangements in order to meet all the requirements of environmental and social aspects to continue with the execution of the upgrading in the Barrancabermeja refinery. Additionally, we have scheduled maintenance at some units in the Barrancabermeja refinery. We also shall continue all efforts to maintain the improving trend in HSE, as well as the safety and reliability of our operations.

Regarding our commercial strategy, we will increase export volumes according to the production growth. Locally, we will begin the activities to be prepared in order to comply with a sulfur content regulation for diesel of less than 50 parts per million across the country, which is mandatory starting January 1, 2013. In biofuels, we will continue with the project to produce ethanol from sugarcane through bioenergy.
Now I open the session to questions from our participants.
Your first question comes from the line of Frank McGann from Bank of America. Please proceed.

Yeah, hi. Good afternoon. I was just wondering – two questions if I could. One is on production, the trend in production during the quarter, and then maybe perhaps if you have some indication of where it is today or what it was in April, if we've seen an increase from the levels you had in the first quarter.

And then the second question on the refining side. Refining, if you look back three or four years, was actually a pretty good earnings contributor. It's been much less robust clearly over the last couple of years, and the first quarter continued that trend. And we're just wondering with prices essentially in line with international prices or moving in line with international prices, when could we expect some improvement in refining? Do we need to see the completions of the upgrades, so your product mix is substantially better, or could we see some improvement over the near term?
Thank you, Frank, again. (32:27) explain – excuse me, Enrique is going to explain about the levels of production in April, how we are doing these days. Okay. Enrique, please.

Hi, Frank. Yes, as Mr. Gutiérrez said, are planning to complete the goal, which is 1,800 by the end of the year. And basically the idea is to maintain the fuels in the production and recuperate, let's say, or increase better our production that we have in the last two months. So we expect to complete the plan. Okay, Frank?
What are the current efforts, Enrique?

Okay. Maybe you have just seen in the report, total production for the Group is 743,000 barrels, divided 626,000 from crude and 116,000 from gas, for Mcf equivalent, as I mentioned before, of 743,000 barrels of equivalent per day.
Okay. And if you look at the trend during the quarter and then in April, has it been basically kind of flat at that level during the three months, and then into April as well?
Yes, for April, but we are planning to start climbing up in May.
Okay. Which years we will see the improvement?

Frank, excuse me, but it is also important to mention that really on the first quarter we were very close to our projection. Really the difference is less than 2%, and notwithstanding that we have some troubles we already (34:33) mentioned in the transportation. Finally, the difference, as you can see, is really small. But it's also show, how the positive evolution in terms of the production.

Yeah. And regarding the question which activities we will complete in the next month, basically if I remember that we have some, I mean, problems in the Caño Limon-Coveñas pipeline, which reduces our production in 17,400 barrels per day as well as some minor cuts in Rubiales due to the increase in water cut. So as soon as we – and we already did. We sold these products where we'll, I mean, keep the momentum in order to complete the goal. Okay?
Okay.
Okay. Turn to Pedro Rosales.
About the refinery?
About the refinery, yeah.

The situation of the first quarter is mainly generated by unscheduled turnaround of the (35:52), which reduced the feed in almost 30,000 barrels per day, and therefore the production of gasoline affecting the valuable produce index.

But in general, the comparison factor of our refineries that is around 75% give us a high dependence on the international margins to generate earnings. Then, as you said, the structural solution will be generated by the modernization of our refineries. That reduces the cost of the crude and increase the quantity and value of our products. Then, in the near term, we would see the results depending on the international market margin. But in the – at the end of the project, we will show a structural efficiency of our refineries given by the increase of the conversion factor that goes from 75% to 95%.

This is the – in terms of the structural change anyway, we have been implemented some initiatives to reduce the costs. And additionally, we have been developing some maintenance activities to increase the reliability, and in general the integrity of our refineries and we have been improving the available capacity of both of our refineries.
And your next question comes from the line of Paula Kovarsky from Itaú. Please proceed.

Hi, everyone. Just wanted to make two questions as well. Just following a little bit on the production again what would have been your recurring production in the first quarter if we were to eliminate the problems with transportation and this little problem in Rubiales? I mean would it be correct to assume that – so you mentioned 17,000 barrels a day of curtailment of production due to the pipeline issue. But this was concentrated in February only. So could you please just tell us what would have been production according to plan excluding those two "non-recurring items"? And then just for us to understand, how far you are from the target of year-end?

And then second question relates to the cost and expenses. We observed a reduction in cost and expenses for – and also in the – a little bit in the operating costs in the first quarter of 2012 compared to the fourth quarter of 2011. And if you could also give us some color on how recurring this reduction is this? Is this any reference for cost and expenses for us to forecast going forward?
Okay. You're right in your consideration. Enrique is going to confirm your estimation. Please, Enrique.
Hi, Paula. Regarding your question the production without any incidents would be around 760,000.
Seven hundred and – sorry?
Okay.
Okay. The 17 are estimated in an average rate.
On a quarterly basis for the quarter?
Yes, for the quarter.
Okay.
And just for the information, Paula, today production is 767,000, 7-6-7, okay?

Okay. Perfect. Then if I may follow-up on that quickly. Looking at future growth and the number of barrels that Ecopetrol has to prove between now and 2015 or even if we look until 2020 and the target of proving another 6 billion barrels. How comfortable the company is in the ability of proving those barrels in the short term to support the fantastic production growth that you guys have been delivering so far, and which would be the main sources of reserves addition in the very short term?

Paula, as you know, we plan for the year to drill more than 400 development wells. So this is one of the task that we expect to accomplish in order to achieve our production. I mean, as you know, almost 90% of production comes from primary recovery.

Okay. But if I look at – it's not only about growing production, you also have to prove the wells to support – even to support our forecast of production growth. So if you could perhaps comment on which are the main two or three reserves – reserve contribution that you expect to see building into the 1.7 billion barrels of proven reserves in short term?
May you explain (42:11) your comment?

Yeah. Just to understand where do you expect new proven barrels to come from? Is it mostly primary out of those 400 development wells that you're going to drill? How much do you expect additional recovery factor to contribute to proving reserves in the short term or more perhaps within this target of proving 6 billion barrels in 2020?
Oh, yes, okay. In the short term --
Let me mention some activities that we will carry out in the next year.

Okay. But – excuse me, Enrique. But it is important to mention that you are referring to the 6 billion barrels that we are referring we are going to add during the next – during the period of 10 years. Okay?
Yes, perfect. But then, I know that's the reference number, but I was just trying to get a little bit more color on the short-term targets.

Okay, (43:18). It means that we are going to add in average a number between 500 and 600 barrels per year approximately, and almost 3.3 million barrels are going to be for the development of our current field, mainly primary, secondary and tertiary recovery. And then we expect to add reserves basically from the national and international exploration considering parts of our current fields and new idea and additionally we also are expecting to add some reserves from the non-conventional resources.

During the first year we are mainly adding from our current fields, but anyway we have been adding some from our new discoveries, and mainly in the short term we are expecting it to continue increasing our recovery factor. Right now we are around 18% and what we are trying is going to around 34%. It implies that – it means in average we must increase our recovery factor at an average of 1.5 per year approximately to be able to add almost 3.3 million barrel from – increase from recovery basically. This is the general picture, yes. For this year, we are mainly supported in the plan on recovery and also some projects for secondary recovery and also tertiary recovery. But it is important to mention that we are – we have also revealed we are in the process of the development of Cano Sur there was a discovery that we had last year.
Okay.

And as Mr. Gutiérrez said, we have 88% of fields in primary recovery but we are also undertaking EUR, IUR (45:55) pilots in order to administer through secondary and tertiary recovery techniques. For instance, we had a pilot for (46:04) Tisquirama, (46:09) chemical injection in San Francisco field as well as gas injection. And as you are aware, we are starting the in-situ combustion in Chichimene and Quifa.
Okay. Thank you. Thank you so much.
You're welcome.
Okay. Now we're going to the explanation about the expenses, working expenses. Adriana Echeverri, our Chief Financial Officer, is going to take the answer.

Hi, Paula. More than savings, what you have to first take into account is that Ecopetrol's execution of cost and expenses has certain cyclicalities, we could say. So by the fourth quarter of every yea, you will find declining cost and expenses because the moving part of the execution takes place during that quarter. That's why when you take a look into the first quarter of next year you find a continuity on that. First quarter usually is characterized by low execution of products due to the fact that we are starting to stand in terms of reference of different selection processes and we are starting to contract delivery. So that's why we find kind of that behavior. So it's better try to compare the first quarter of one year with the first quarter of the next or the last with the last. That's the real situation that happens every year in the company.
And your next question comes from the line of Caio Carvalhal. Please proceed.
Hi, Paula, (48:03).
Hi. Can I make the question? This is Caio.
Excuse me, let's – okay. Hi. How are you?
I'm sorry, I'm not sure if you want to make any comments on Paula's question, or should I put mine now?
Go ahead. Proceed with your question.
Go ahead.
Okay, great. Thanks a lot. .
Enough for Paula, but anyway we are open for additional explanation. Okay, go ahead.

Actually my question is on the operational side as well. I have one question referring production and again another one on refining. I think it's pretty much actually a clarification on both Frank's and Paula's question so far.

On the production side, if I understood right, the problems of that 17,000 barrels a day that you missed in production was because of the transportation issues you had with the pipeline, right? I just want to confirm that that was the main issue. It was transportation or did we had any type of, let's say, lower than expected increase in production?

In addition, also on this question, if you could just tell me – I'm not sure if you can open that, but if you could just tell me from the proper produced volumes how much came from each one of the five or six main fields Ecopetrol controls?

And lastly also on the production, I understood the last part of the comments mentioning about chemical injection, the in-situ combustion. I mean, are these projects performing as expected? Because in the last guidance we understood that four or five critical fields were under some operational upgrade that were critical to increase production. And also just a final comment on production. On Chichimene you mentioned right now like 30 seconds ago that the in-situ combustion in Chichimene has already started. I understood this was target only for the end of the year. If you could update me on how this product state is going on I would be more than happy. Many thanks.

Okay. Basically you have four questions, okay. One in relation with the impact of the transportation, okay. The second one is how we can split the production and the main areas that we are operating – the main fields that we are operating. Chichimene, okay, (50:41) combustion but really we are developing, okay. Okay, these three, yes.
Yeah.

Okay. Actually it was like five questions in one. Let me one by one answer you, Caio. The first one, the final run, you were asking if all the differential in production came from transportation. The answer is not. I mean, the – as you know, there were some attacks on the infrastructure in Caño Limon-Coveñas, okay? The first question. Second one is the status on the Chichimene (51:21). Let me tell you that we are in the early structuring stages, so in – and we are kind of working in a customized technology for the field. And your question regarding production by fields, Cartagena is almost 101,000. I'm going to give you some rough numbers, okay?
Okay, fine. The big numbers are fine.

Yeah. Wahira (51:51) is like 60,000 barrels equivalent, Rubiales is 97,000, and others including FPI is like 22,000. Okay? La Cira-Infantas, the LCI field in Middle Mag is 20,000, Casabe in the Middle Mag is 22,000, Nare is 17,000, and Chichimene is 43,000 barrels per share. Let me clarify, is Ecopetrol's net working interest. Okay?

Okay. Perfect. Thanks a lot. Yes, and it covers my question. On the downstream, it's, I couldn't totally understand – understood the answer you guys gave to Frank McGann. I mean, it really puzzles me why the downstream segment has been delivering interesting result up until two quarters ago. My question would be, shall we expect over the next quarters in 2012 the downstream segment to deliver negative results? Or this was – again, I understand you guys already answered that, but I couldn't understand the answer. Or shall we expect it to change only when you have the upgrades in Barrancabermeja and Cartagena done?

Okay. Caio, Pedro Rosales. Mainly the situation in this quarter was generated by a scheduled turnaround of the main plant for the processing unit in Barrancabaermeja refinery, and at the same time in Cartagena (53:35), that was an unscheduled maintenance. It's not a thing that with us we didn't consider is planned this maintenance. Its maintenance is made every five years. Then in this time we had this situation. Additionally, we took (54:02) with the projects we will develop new strengths on the refinery cost. We can't use crudes that have a lower cost and produce more products.
